Anderson was arrested on suspicion the following day and a wiman iden», fified him as the man she had seen running from the scene of the mur= der, A strong circumstantial case built against him and an overcoat found at the scene of the murder was identified as one purchased by him the day before the murder, While in Jail awaiting trial, he tried to persuade a fellow prisoner who was incarcerated on a minor  h ¢ d in persons who Anderson feared would testify gaggggttgiQFr ﬁgigeﬁgglnogggggg t§é~polgce and toid them that Andér~ son had told him that he had shot Logan when Logan resisted the robbery attempt,. At his trial, Anderson claimed that he had "blacked out" and had no recollection of the murder, His conviction and the sentence of death were affirmed on appeal and he was XXX« hanged at the Oregon on July 2, 1909, — On the night preceding his death, a knife was found hidden in a shoebox in his cell and it was believed that he had planned to either commit suicide or to try to kill some of the officials at his execution. big_ocr: AH LEE  Ah Lee, alias Lee Jaw, was a Chinese Laborer who lived in Portland, Ore, On October 2, 1878, another Chinese, Chin Sue Ying, who had been converted to Christianity and who was attneding a mission school., entered the Chinese Joss house located on Second Avenue and was accused by Charley Lee Quong of having exploded a Chinese stink bomb, At the request of Charley Lee Quong, a policeman forcibly ejected Chin Sue Ying and when the policeman asked Charley Lee Quong why he did not have Chin Sue Ying arrested, he replied that he would do so on the following day, On October 3, Chin Sue Ying, accompanied by two other converted Chinese, returned to the joss house and was preparing to throw a piece of raw meat on the joss when Ah Lee stepped up behind him and struck him twice on the head with am hatchet, Charley Lee Cuong and Lee Jong then each drew pistols and shot him in the abdomen, Before his death on October 5, Chin Sue Ying made a dying declaration in which he accused Ah Lee of having cut him and the other two men of having shot him, Ah Lee and Charley Lee Quong were both arrested and they were indicted for the murder with Lee Jong who fled the cquntry before he could be arrested, At their trial, Both Ah Lee and Charly Lee Nuong sought to prove and alibi and their friends testified that Lee Jong alone had attacked Chin Sue Ying, Chin Sue Ying‘s two fellow Christians both testified that Ah Lee had weilded the hatchet while Charley Lee Quong and Lee Jong had shot Chin Sue Ying, Both Ah Lee and Charley Leeuong were convicted and sentenced to die but the con» victions were reversed by the Oregon Supreme Court on Appeal, At their second trial, they were granted a severance and Ah Lee was sentenced t¢ die while Charley Lee Quong was sentenced to life imprisonment, This second conviction was affirmed on appeal and on April 20, 1880, he was hanged at the jail in Portland, Even though his emotion was visible, Ah Lee marched to the scaffold ted big_ocr: CAVERY, Eugene L, and JOHNSON, James  Avery, alias Archie Brown, a 25—year=old white native of Watertown, Wis., moved to California as a youth and became a highwayman and the leader of a gang, While serving a sentence at San Quenin, he met Johnson, also 25, whose,real name was never revealed but who was a member of a prominent California family who had fallen afoul of the law and been sent to San Quentin, After their release, they went to Portland, Ure., for the purpose of casing some banks for future robb» eries, While there, they met a 16—year=old youth, Joseph Swoards, and on t he morning of August 20, 1878, the three of them went into the pawn shop owned by Walter O‘Shea on Washington Street between Lst and 2nd Avemies, locking the door behind them, After knocking O‘Sheax un— conscious with an iron bar, they looted the safe and escaped through  a back window, A passerby observed them leaving through the window and notified a police officer who chased then for several blocks,. Fi— nally, the three men drew pistols, turned towards the officer and be» gan firing, The officer took shelfer behind a tree and one of the bullets from Avery‘s gun ricocheted off the tree and pierced the heart  of a young boy, Louis Joseph, killing him instantly, |The three mon  then leaped into a grocery wagon_garked by the sidewalk and fled to  some dense timber on the edge of town and escaped. Swoards was arrest— ed in a Portland saloon on August 23 and confessed to having taken  part in the robbery of O‘Shea‘s shop, naming Avery and Johnson as his accomplices, Avery was captured on a ranch outside of Portland on Sep 3, while Johnson was taken into custody in Los Angeles on Oct, L:.  At their trial, all three were convicted and Avery and Johnson were sentenced to die while Swoards! life was spared because of his youth and kkx he was sentenced to life imprisonment, The convictions were affirmed on appeal and, after receivéirig one respite, Avery and John» son were hanged behind a stockade in the jail yard at Portland on March 14, 1879. Both men went to their deaths bravely and Brown made a lengthy speech from the gallows in which he admitted that he had committed many crimes but claimed that the killing of young Joseph was accidental, On one occasion, his partner Johnson interrupted his speech during the course of which he had sang two songs, saying: "Brown, I wish you would speak to the point if you have anything to say, This suspense is terrible to me," When Avery had finally finish» ed his remarks, Johnson merely said: "I die the victim of judicial murder,? after which, Brown admonished him to believe in Christ (John» son was an athiest.) big_ocr: BALCH; Danford  Balch, a white man, resided with his wife and family about! one mile west of Portland, Multnomah Co,, Ore, He and his wife abject: ed tbhethe courtship of one of their daughters by a young mane® named Mortimer Stump and forbade the girl to see him, Miss Balch eloped with Nr, Stump and they were married in Portland on November 18,  1858, When Balch learned that they bad left together, he armed him«= self with a shotgun loaded with bugekshot and followed them to the Stark Street ferry boat which he also boarded. While Mr, and Mrs3, Stump stood talking with Stmmp‘s father, Balch walked to them on the slip of the boat and fired the gun at Stump‘s head, The load took effect in the head and neck, killing him instantly, Balch promptly surrendered himself to the authorities in Portland and was placed in jail, On April 27, 1859, he and three other prisoners managed to es» cape from custody but Balch remained in the vicinity, frequently visiting and staying in his bwn home, He was recaptured there several weeks later and on August 17 he was tried, convicted and sentenced to die for the murder, Prior to the execution, he told his spiritual ad» viser that he had not intended to kill Stump and had taken the weapon with him for self—defence when he went in search of his daughter,. John C.,  Barnes, a white man, was a resident of Douglas Co., Ore., who had served a term in the state penitentiary for larceny, After his re— lease, he was sentenced to 20—years imprisonment for the rape of his 1?—yeareold half—sister but he was pardoned seven years later by Gov, Sylvester Pennoyer who received much criticism for his action,. After his release from prison, Barnes became a gold.miner and set up camp on Dodd‘s Creek in Douglas County near that of another miner, William Graham, Several months Bater, on April 27, 1906, Barnes moved to a point several miles away on Tuller‘s Creek and set up a new camp.. The next day, he borrowed a rifle from a neighbor saying that he planned to go hunting and that night, while talking to two visitors at his camp,remarked that Graham was a bad man who he would not hesitate to kill, He left early the next morning before his visi= tors had awakened, and was seen going in the direction of Graham‘s camp» That night, he appeared in Glendale and payed a bill with a special piece of gold that had been molded for Graham, receiving cash in exchange for the difference in the value of it and his account,  While drinking in a saloon, he displayed a pistol which another man knew to be Grgham‘s and when éskedpabgut it he said‘ that he had pur=  chased it from Graham, On the morning of May 1, a ¥mwm skeleton, the flesh consumed by fire, was found near Graham s camp and nearby was a hat and other articles of clothing belonging to Graham, The body was identified bs that of Graham because the skeleton corresponded to his size and by the presence of the items known to have been worn by Graham when last, seen, When taken into custody, Barnes denied that he had killed Graham and, in spite of the fact that he had previously told a man that he had recently purchased the pistol, he said that it had been his for some time, While awaiting trial, he attempted to escape from jail, ‘At his trial, his defense was based on uncertainty as to the identity of the skeleton and lack of motive for murder, He did not take the stand in his own behalf and he was convicted and sentenced to die, The case was unsuceessfully appealed to the State Supreme Court and when Governor Chamberlain declined to commute the sentence, he was hanged at the State Prison on Sept, 18, 1906, He went to his death calmly and made a brief speech .in which he said: "Gentlemen, this is not going to be an execution; this is murder, I expect to die like a man, Although Governor Chamberlain has not saw fit to pardon me, I am ready to die, But, this not an execution; it is murder," He then asked that hymn number 5 from the prison song book KNXKXX be sung but, as no person present knew the song, this re»  uest was denied 85 PACIFIC 998 — OREGON JOURNAL. big_ocr: EGBER, Harry D.  Esbert, a ?7—year—old white man, was born John H, Frost in Audubon ‘Co., Iowa,. Adopted in infancy by a family named Egbert, he was given the name Harry D. Egbert, but in later life occasionally used the name Jack Frost as an alias, After graduating from high school, he entered his first criminal venture when he operated an illicit saloon in a dry city, He subsequently moved to Oregon in 1900 and in Oct,, 1901, was sentenced to the penitentiary there for horse theft, In the summer of 1903, a warrant was issued for his arrest for a burgla«= ry committed at Drain Oregon, In September he was traced to the Juni—= per ranch near Burns in Harney County and a warrant was sent from Douglas County for his arrest,. Deputy Sheriffs Jack Saxton and John West went to the ranch to serve the warrant and allowed Egbert to en— ter the house to say goodbye to the woman with whom he was living in a comman—~law relationship,. He sscaped through a rear window and made his way to the KXKKk Fields ranch in the Wild Horse Section where he was again located on October h}, When Saxton and West arrived there, he opened fire op them from within the house and West was felled by  his first shots, Saxton managed to make his way to the house and he and Egbert continued firing at each other through the wails. Vests  mortally wounded, pleaded for water and when Saxton took him some, Egbert shot and killed him from an upstairs window, He fled into Nevada and was tracked from there to Rockland, Idaho, by a constable who was stimulated by the reward and arrested there on October 26, His conviction was not appealed and at 12:2 on the afternoon of Jan. 29, 1904, he became the first man to be executed at the Oregon State Prisonyin thepresence of 75 witnesses. Egbert never lost his nerve even. though he was deathly pale and nerouyvsly puffed on a cigarette as he mounted the gallows unassisted after eating a last meal of canned pears and cream as he had requested, He mde a—brief speech from the gallows in which he urged witnessesto keep their children out of saloons and away from bad company and closed with the words:? "My heart is too full to say anything more," Several of the witnesses left the room before the black cap was placed over his eyes and one of the witnesses, a medical student, fainted as the trap fell, As his body was not claimed by relatives or friends, it was given to the Medical College at Willamette University for dissestion,  TIMES—HERALD, Burns, Oregon, Jan, 30, 1904 and Feb, 6, 1901. j PORTLAND ORRONIAN, Portland, Ore., Jan, 30, 190}; (Photo on page six) HARNEY COUNTY, OREGON, AND ITSRANGE LAND by George Francis Brimlow, Published, 1951, by Binfords and Mort, Portland, Oregons Page 220
